What is the purpose of the Fee Pool in the Verus protocol?

The Fee Pool in the Verus protocol collects fees paid by users when they interact with the protocol. These fees come from various activities such as creating a PBaaS-chain, creating a currency or token, registering a VerusID, making conversions, and executing transactions. The Fee Pool rewards miners and stakers for their work in securing the blockchain and servicing the Verus economy.

for finding a new block), they also take a small portion of the Fee Pool. The Fee Pool collects fees that are paid by users when they are interacting with the protocol. Protocol fees include:
PBaaS-chain: creating a blockchain on Verus costs 10,000 VRSC. 5,000 VRSC goes into the Verus Fee Pool, and 5,000 VRSC goes into the Fee Pool of the created blockchain, earned by miners and stakers of that blockchain
(DeFi) Currency and tokens: creating a currency on the Verus blockchain costs 200 VRSC
VerusID: identity fees for miners and stakers are 20, 40, 60, 80 or 100 VRSC
subID: under launched currencies and tokens subIDs can be created, these cost 0.02 VRSC
Conversion fees: each time a user converts currencies it costs 0.025% or 0.05% — miners and stakers get 50% of these fees
Transaction fees: each transaction is minimally 0.0001 VRSC
Miners and stakers are protecting the blockchain and at the same time servicing the Verus economy. We expect the Fee Pool rewards to exceed the coinbase rewards.
Think about it: someone creates a PBaaS-chain, 5,000 VRSC goes to the Fee Pool, the winner of the next block gets 50 VRSC extra on top of the coinbase reward. Now imagine a whole lot of economic activity: users making conversions through the protocol, registering VerusIDs, creating DeFi currencies and tokens, and the Fee Pool can get quite large.
Verus Fee Pool. Percentage is subject to change before hitting mainnet.
Merge-Mine up to 22 Chains
The example above is only for mining Verus directly. Keep in mind that Verus is a multichain protocol. All PBaaS-chains in the protocol have exactly the same specifications as the Verus mainchain. They too have a Fee Pool that collects fees through VerusID registrations, conversions, DeFi currency and tokens and even in a later stage also PBaaS-chains!
And you can mine 22 of them! All with the same hashrate as you would when mining only Verus

How much does it cost to create a PBaaS-chain on the Verus blockchain, and where do these fees go?

Creating a PBaaS-chain on the Verus blockchain costs 10,000 VRSC. Of this amount, 5,000 VRSC goes into the Verus Fee Pool, and the remaining 5,000 VRSC goes into the Fee Pool of the created blockchain, which is earned by the miners and stakers of that blockchain.

The fees for VerusID registrations are 20, 40, 60, 80, or 100 VRSC, depending on the type of registration. These fees are collected in the Fee Pool and rewarded to miners and stakers for their work in securing the blockchain.

How do conversion fees work, and who benefits from them?

Conversion fees are charged to users when they convert currencies using the Verus protocol. The fee is either 0.025% or 0.05% of the converted amount. Miners and stakers receive 50% of these fees as a reward for their work in securing the blockchain.

What is the significance of the Verus protocol being a multichain protocol, and how does this affect mining?

The Verus protocol being a multichain protocol means that all PBaaS-chains in the protocol have the same specifications as the Verus mainchain. Each of these chains has its own Fee Pool, which collects fees from various activities such as VerusID registrations, conversions, and DeFi currency and token creations. Miners can merge-mine up to 22 of these chains simultaneously, using the same hashrate as they would when mining only Verus. This allows miners to benefit from the Fee Pools of multiple chains.
